title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Good evening,
I need these 2 small IC (see photo) for a motherboard MacBook Air 13 "A1466 820-00165.
It's 2 small ICs (mosfets normally) are for backlighting.
I do not know where to order them.
I also have another 820-00165 that starts, but no backlight.
The 2 IC are OK, the chip on the back of the screen connector (the driver of the backlight) is OK too, the fuse too, but still nothing.
I suspect maybe the IC U8300 (on the diagram of the motherboard, a mosfet too) but I can not locate it.
It's a shame, on the MacBook Air there are no inscriptions to locate the components, not like the MacBook Pro (17 "anyway).
Cordially.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
The small one is Q7707 and the other is Q7706.
Why do you supose them bad?
What did you measure?
Boardview available for this board, so easy to locate them.

There could be other reason for missing backlight...
Post their voltages for diagnose; with LCD connected, of course.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Thanks for the reference of the components.
I just need it because they miss me for a motherboard.
I have a client who passes my 5 motherboards 820-00165, I have already repaired 3 (including one where I miss the Q7707).
One HS (the BCM15700A2 chip overheating and the motherboard that starts, turns off, starts looping, even if IC remove, the CPU heats up abnormally too) and the other, backlighting problem (Q7707 and Q7706 that works, voltage compared with a functional motherboard), OK fuse and IC backlight OK driver too.
But no backlight yet.
What is Boardview?
I found the OpenBoardView software on Google, but I only have schemas in PDF, not in .PCB as for iPhones / iPad.
Sorry I just arrived on the forum.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Use OpenBoardView for this...
[url]https://drive.google.com/open?id=1tuNFPBr1gVbEtSlW-sF5tCYw1APmCATp[/url]

Pay atention to XW7720 bridge, placed just between L/D7701.
A simply search on the forum should bring up lot of info...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Yes, I saw the XW7720 on the diagram (thanks for that).
But on the motherboard, between the coil and the diode, I have nothing.
I saw after that I could test it differently by measuring on the capacitors, I would do that.
Motherboard : 820-00165-A.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
You can find "real" pictures of XW7720 searching the forum.
That small point gets corroded many times...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Good evening,
I saw that it was actually a pad.
It is present on the motherboard, and it is not oxidized.
I tested with a functional motherboard and connected screen, I must have 25V at this place.
But on the motherboard with HS backlight, I have nothing in this place, and even the surrounding components.
I have the 8.5V that comes out of the fuse and goes to Q7706 and Q7707.
But I have nothing in XW7720, L7701, D7701, C7797, C7799 ...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message: Do you get image, only backlight missing?

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Yes, I have an image.
I just miss the backlight.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Post voltages for Q7706/07.
Also check BKL_EN and BKL_PWM.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Q7706:
I have 8.5V on pin 4, so I get the power of F7700.
I have 8.3V on pin 3.
And I have nothing, 0V, on others.
Q7707:
I have 2.45V on 6 and 4 out of 5 I have 3.29V.
On 3 I have 5,12V, 2 I have 3.29V and on 1 (GND) I have 0V.
For BKL_EN and BKL_PWM I have 0V.
Sometimes I get to have a voltage on XW7720, just now I managed to have 8.5V after cleaning, while it was clean, then nothing after.
There earlier, I had 2V then the voltage dropped, at first I had nothing, the tension came after a while.
I have already changed 2x U7701 in doubt, the same.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Q7707 looks bad, change it.
If pins 2 & 5 have high voltage, all the others should be low.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Hello,
I bought a dozen Q7706 and Q7707, so I'll have in stock.
Now with a new Q7707, I have 8.5V at XW7720 instead of 0V.
Have advance.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Do a PRAM reset and post again BKL_EN (R7715) and BKL_PWM (C7704).
Be sure U7701 is properly soldered.
Check continuity from its ball A5 to D7701.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
On R7715 I have 2.5V.
C7704, 2.80V.
I have continuity between A5 U7701 and D7701.
I also realized that I have nothing, 0V, on XW7720, but I have 8.5V on the components around.
I have rechanged U7701.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Put the working board in same case and test LCD assembly.
If you have BKLT_EN and BKLT_PWM at U7701, backlight circuit is enabled.

"I have nothing, 0V, on XW7720"
You must have the same voltage as in cathode of D7701; what voltage is there?

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
When all assembled, the same, I have an image but no backlight.
I only have 8.5V in the backlight circuit.
I have nothing on XW7720, but I have 8.5V on D7701.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
"I have nothing on XW7720, but I have 8.5V on D7701"
This is not possible, unless XW7720 is open circuit.

Check schematic, XW7720 is between D7701 and U7701.
A tiny trace connects the dot of XW7720 with D7701, is that good?

[ATTACH alt="Click image for larger version  Name:	xw7720 fix.jpg Views:	0 Size:	522.5 KB ID:	45765" type="full" width="30%"]45765._xfImport[/ATTACH]

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Good evening,
I retest and in the end I have 8.5V well on XW7720, I had trouble testing or a bug.
But still no backlight.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
"Put the working board in same case and test LCD assembly.
------------------------
When all assembled, the same, I have an image but no backlight."
Working board no image with the same screen???
So bad screen.
I hope you've tested properly...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message: The screen works, it does not worry when I test with other motherboards.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Do you get BKLT_EN and BKLT_PWM at U7701?
Did you try PRAM reset several times?

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
On BKL_EN I have 2.5 / 2.6V.
On BKL_PWM I have 2.8V.
Yes, I reset the PRAM several times.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message: BKLT_EN is too low pretty sure it should be 3.3 volts. Check the resistors for BKLT_EN

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
On R7731, I have 8.5V on pin 1 and 2.5V on pin 2.
On R7715, I have 2.5V on pin 1, but nothing on pin 2.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
"On R7715, I have 2.5V on pin 1, but nothing on pin 2."
Don't you want to get voltage on ground pin, no?

BKL_EN should be 1/3 of PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT, which is (should be) aprox 8.5V.
You should get 2.8V aprox; but even 2.5V is sufficient to enable U7701.

I suppose bad solders for U7701, or bad chip.
Post resistance to ground (diode mode, red probe to ground) for all the connections of U7701.
Use surrounding components as test points...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Hello, yes the pin 2 is GND.
I tested the pins of U7701, no worries, I tested the continuity, see if there were no tracks cut, I did not test the continuity to the ground for all the pins.
I sold a new brand new chip bought on Farnell.
Still no backlight.
I still have 8.5V on XW7720.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
"Post resistance to ground (diode mode, red probe to ground) for all the connections of U7701.
Use surrounding components as test points..."
Do that, so we can confirm good solders...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
I have tested all U7701 pins to earth, except the GND pins, no other is grounded, no resistance to the multimeter (infinite resistance).
I also took the opportunity to note all the tensions of U7701 with a monitor plug:

18: 3.30V
19: 3.30V
20: 0V
21: 0V
22: 0V

24: GND
25: 0V

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
You didn't understand.
Diode mode value on the U7701 pins (red probe to ground) will reveal if you have some bad solder.
Please do what we ask, if you expect help.
WE can NOT measure anything on YOUR board...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
If I understand correctly, I have to put the multimeter in diode mode, the red (+) on the mass, and with the black (-) I test each point of U7701?
I should have what value if good / bad solder on the multimeter?

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Better we try to interpret your values.
Do not exist precise readings.
The values vary, depending on each board and multimeter used...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
You'r multimeter definitely has a problem; 016 from ground to ground???

"15: 1.
-------
20: 1.
21: 1.
22: 1.
23: 1.
--------
25: 1."
All these balls unsoldered; probably many more.
Reflow the chip...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
I flatly change the chip in the end, the same.
Maybe it is actually poorly welded but I even reflect the chip several times and always the same.
Possible that the problem comes on the other hand?

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Return lines should gave all same value, 600-650 aprox (diode mode); if chip is properly soldered.
I hope you remember to always ckeck with red probe at ground...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
The chip is well soldered, no worries.
Still no backlighting though.
When I run the tests while pressing D at startup I have the error PFM006: the SMC present can be a problem.
I did a reset SMC and PRAM / NVRAM but nothing.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Post again the diode mode values for U7701.
I hope you didn't forget to check XW7720; many mentions on the forum about it (pictures too)...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Now post U7701 voltage; C1, C4, A3, A4.
LCD connected, of course...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message: What are C1, C4, A3 and A4 on the schematics / boardview?

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Look at U7701 in schematic.
I prefer to use schematic, instead of boardview...

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
These values look good.
What voltages on both sides of D7701 now?

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
8.55V on the pin 1
8.53V on the pin 2

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message:
Be sure D7701 is not shorted A-K.
Backlight circuit is enabled, but doesn't boost for some reason.
Did you try other display assembly?
Try few PRAM reset.
I still doubt about U7701, or its solders.

title: MacBook Air 13" A1466 820-00165 - Backlight
message: PRAM reset done several times but nothing. The screen is the only one I have but it works perfectly with other motherboard. I have to watch if short circuit and if not replace U7701.
